entry.et: Middle English, from Old English hēr; akin to Old High German hier here, Old English hē he

def.dt: :in or at this place turn here often used interjectionally especially in answering a roll call
:in an arbitrary location a book here, a paper there
:at or in this point, particular, or case here we agree

dt.un: used interjectionally in rebuke or encouragement
used interjectionally to express resolution or resignation especially at the beginning of a difficult or unpleasant undertaking

def.dt: :having no interest or relevance :of no consequence comfort is neither here nor there to a real sailor

dt.un: used for emphasis especially after a demonstrative pronoun or after a noun modified by a demonstrative adjective this book here
used for emphasis after a demonstrative adjective but before the noun modified this here book

def.dt: :the present time used with the man's obligation is in the here and now W. H. Whyte
